definitions.definition: a short surprise attack on an enemy by soldiers, ships or aircraft

examples.text: The air force carried out a **bombing raid** on enemy bases.
The raids against military targets continued.
Guerrillas were carrying out hit-and-run raids on the troops.
He led his men on a cross-border raid.
bombers carrying out daylight raids over northern France

definitions.definition: a surprise visit by the police looking for criminals or for illegal goods or drugs

examples.text: They were arrested during a **dawn raid**.
He was injured during a **police raid** on his nightclub.
Police staged an early morning raid on the premises.
He was taken into custody following a raid on the property by armed police.
the stolen cash seized in last night's raid

definitions.definition: an attack on a building, etc. in order to commit a crime

examples.text: Two customers foiled a raid on a local post office.
She was shot during an armed raid on a security van.
the jewels stolen in the raid

wordOrigin: late Middle English (as a noun): Scots variant of road in the early senses ‘journey on horseback’, ‘foray’. The noun became rare from the end of the 16th cent. but was revived by Sir Walter Scott; the verb dates from the mid 19th cent.
